question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I very much liked the homework design and thought it accompanied the class well, including the Cafe Ivrit conversation hours that were held to encourage outside-of-class interaction with Hebrew. One of the other major components of the course was the portfolio, which was helpful but also a bit ambiguous in its purpose. As a place to summarize out-of-class Hebrew experiences (this was my interpretation), I found this helpful, but then I don't understand the point of spending valuable time on formatting rather than the content. I was also seeing different interpretations throughout the class. If this is truly meant to be a "choose your own adventure" style of project, I would recommend grading it as such—if people don't think formatting is going to be intellectually stimulating, look to the components they list. If there was a more material realization to the project, I would recommend providing some examples so people can focus their effort on the intellectually-stimulating task at hand.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think my biggest wish was that had done more that applied to current times and modern Hebrew versus all the grammar and structure of sentences, for example. I know that grammar is obviously an important part of the language, but I think it is also important to learn about things beyond the rules. For example, it would have been cool to have a class on Israeli slang, and see what words and phrases are actually very common in Israel. I also wish we had done a bit more with pop culture. We had a poet come in to speak to us and we read his work, and I really enjoyed that, so I think doing more of that or watching an episode of an Israeli TV show or listening to Israeli songs and talking about them could be very beneficial. Basically, I just think we should have done more that exposed us to real Israeli culture (that would also help with our understanding of the language) than we did.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are looking to do Hebrew for your language requirement I highly recommend it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I took Hebrew for all of my growing up life, and was really excited to improve my speaking skills by taking it at Duke. Whatever I was expecting, though, was not what I was met with. Prof. Baker is very kind, enthusiastic, and fair in her assignments and her grading; that said, we spent the entire semester reviewing grammar forms that I learned in middle school and early high school.While this was a nice review, I can confidently say that I did not learn speak and write any more fluently, did not pick up any slang or the ability to watch fast-paced Hebrew movies, and did not read real Hebrew literature. We worked out of a workbook the entire semester, only read news articles on a platform with small articles meant for Hebrew beginners, and even when we expressed the desire to learn from more applicable sources were not met with engaging, challenging material. Classes were essentially a lecture, with hardly any Hebrew spoken by us. This would have been a good intermediate class, but was definitely not meant to be a 300-level language course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is definitely a lot of work. Most of the homework is helpful but sometimes can feel like busy work, and a lot of in class time it feels like we spend just going over the same things. However, I have definitely learned a lot in this class.

response_text: This class will help you tremendously improve your speaking, writing, and grammar skills, in addition to getting exposed to a wide array of Israeli culture.
